posts.name: rsegrest
posts.cooked:
Hello CD Experts, our team is looking into purchasing a laser cutter for next season. I have searched CD and the most recent posts I have found are dated pre-2020. We are looking for:  
120+ Watt, 4’ x 4’ bed, less than $7,000 (less than $5,000 would be amazing but probably not reasonable). Does anyone have a laser cutter that they absolutely love and could not live without? TIA.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: rsegrest commented, "120+ Watt." IMO, a 60W machine can do anything you need for FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC). I’d pay more attention to the overall quality of the machine than the wattage. A relevant adage here: "What is cheap, is expensive."

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
The following is a cleaned-up version of the text:

"Polycarb can be cut in both 1/8 inch and 1/4 inch thickness. Be warned that results may vary greatly—expect poor quality at best and terrible cuts at worst. Ensure your ventilation is properly set up before cutting polycarb, as the fumes are highly corrosive and particularly challenging with 1/4-inch material. Delrin is a great choice for cutting because it tends to vaporize cleanly during cuts rather than melt, making it easier to avoid mistakes. Acrylic produces the nicest cuts among plastics, but its brittleness limits its practical use to aesthetic purposes. Always opt for low-power settings and make multiple passes when cutting plastics like these. Assistant: I think that's about right."

This version removes all HTML tags, preserves the original meaning, and ensures proper grammar and punctuation while maintaining a natural flow of ideas.

posts.name: rsegrest
posts.cooked: You have no idea how much I appreciate the advice! I'm not the engineering expert, just the IT teacher who knows a lot about engineering—from learning it through involvement with FRC 18 years ago. Anything else you might recommend we watch out for? We plan to use the laser cutter for quick prototyping with plywood and bumper frames. For our builds, polycarb is mainly used for protecting components and occasionally for structural pieces—for example, this year we made our coral intake using both 1/8 and 1/4 polycarb. Last year, our under-the-bumper and over-the-frame intake had polycarb side plates. I thought the laser cutter might be a better option for those cuts, freeing up the CNC for aluminum work.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
After reviewing my initial attempt, I realize I might have missed something. Let me try again.

Be prepared to service the thing and replace the lenses/mirrors on a scheduled basis.

Really lean into the fact that part turnover on a laser is lightning fast, and use it to iterate rapidly. You don’t need to waste time on a mill/router until you know the dimensions once you have a laser - so, don’t.

Lasers are a really good "first CNC machine" experience for students, because there’s no work holding and it’s relatively hard to make the machine damage itself. Make use of that in your training sequence.

Let your students have fun making art on the laser when it’s not in use for other things. Engraving is cool, and is a good low-stakes way to practice fine-tuning the machine settings.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
There are several laser options available. I have owned two of them—a CO2 laser and a 30W fiber laser. Initially, I struggled with engraving aluminum, finding it difficult to achieve the desired results. However, when I switched to using spray marking instead, I noticed significant improvement.

As for your advice, if you keep your laser operating at 100% power constantly, the lifespan of the laser tube will diminish significantly. Typically, the laser tube lasts about half its original duration under such conditions. This is something to consider if you plan to use the laser frequently at maximum power.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Now, here’s the cleaned-up version:

"Now, this is if you spend a lot of time at 100%. Don’t. As I mentioned above, the best strategy for both cut quality and tool longevity is to run at lower duty cycles for multiple passes. This takes longer, but the laser is already such a fast machine that the difference doesn’t matter much. Shoutout to the University of Maryland for teaching me these best practices as a research intern."

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
The text is now cleaned up and reformatted into a single coherent paragraph while preserving its original meaning. Here is the revised version:

---

Anyone buying a laser now, IMO, should plan around SRPP becoming a major part of their workflow for production robot parts. REV Robotics offers MAXComposite Sheets, designed for STEM education and commonly used in FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) projects. WestCoast Products provides SRPP Sheets, which are lightweight yet highly durable, making them ideal for applications like intakes and bumpers. Both products are excellent choices for FRC teams. Additionally, REV Robotics provides machining guidelines for MAXComposite on their website, suggesting that investing in a 100W machine could significantly improve your workflow.

---

a 100W 2×3 ThunderLaser and still recommend them. If we were buying again, we'd buy as much wattage and area as we could afford and fit. A 150W 3×4 model would likely be most suitable. The additional wattage allows for thicker materials and faster cutting, while the larger surface area enables tasks like full-size belly pans, robot covers, and larger sponsor panels. OMtech appears to be priced competitively and has positive reviews. As for xTool, they are introducing promising options, including some for metal cutting. However, I require more information about their new machine before I can fully recommend it. posts.name: Jackie Gerstein
posts.cooked:
I've got an Aeon Mira 9 and a 30W fiber galvo laser. I love both machines, but the Mira 9 is well out of your budget and the galvo isn't going to do what you need. We are looking for: 120+ Watt, 4’ x 4’ bed, and less than $7k ($5k would be amazing but probably not reasonable). I’m not aware of anything that meets all these requirements. Which of your criteria are non-negotiable, and what can you be flexible on? Also, have you budgeted for ventilation? If you aren’t able to vent the laser outside, you’ll need to budget for a fume extractor and regular filter replacements, which will eat into your budget pretty significantly.

The main materials we want to use it for are: plywood up to 1" thickness, polycarb both 1/8" and 1/4" thickness, and aluminum engraving. I love laser cutters, but between the size and the materials, this is really starting to sound more like a CNC router than a laser cutter to me.

Plywood: Cutting 1" thickness on a laser is possible with a high-power CO2 laser and patience, but above 3/4" it’s often more practical to consider a CNC router. Polycarbonate: Not ideal for lasers—expect slow cuts, poor finish, and lots of fumes. Aluminum: Can mark with cermark or similar solutions, but proper engraving isn’t feasible.

We want to use the laser cutter for quick prototyping with plywood and bumper frames. My initial thought was that the laser might be a better option for those cuts and free up the CNC for aluminum work. Perfect - this is a great use case. Prototyping in cardboard and plywood saves time and material costs compared to the CNC router. However, does a 4’x4’ 120W laser really make sense for prototyping? My team used a 24"x18" 60W laser, and it rarely felt like a bottleneck.

Laser cutter vs. CNC router decisions depend on materials and application. For your specific needs, plywood and polycarb may be better suited to the laser, but aluminum would still likely be a CNC job. When it comes to buying a laser, consider your budget and priorities. Most lasers in your price range are glass tube models requiring water cooling, so plan accordingly. RF tube lasers offer higher power and longer lifespan without water cooling, though they are pricier.

Some recommendations: Thunder Laser offers good value and reliability. Omtech’s 2028 series, particularly the 4063 150W model, is a strong contender. Hao-Tian also has affordable fiber galvo options worth exploring.
